description: From Middle English rusty, from Old English rūstiġ (“rusty”), from Proto-Germanic *rustagaz (“rusty”), equivalent to rust +‎ -y. Cognate with Saterland Frisian rusterch (“rusty”), West Frisian rustich, roastich (“rusty”), Dutch roestig (“rusty”), German Low German rusterig, rüsterig (“rusty”), German rostig (“rusty”), Swedish rostig (“rusty”).

entries.meaning: Marked or corroded by rust. [from 9th c.]
Of the rust color, reddish or reddish-brown. [from 14th c.]
examples: Alive? he might be dead for aught I know, / With that red gaunt and colloped neck a-strain, / And shut eyes underneath the rusty mane;

entries.meaning: Lacking recent experience, out of practice, especially with respect to a skill or activity. [from 16th c.]
(now chiefly historical) Of clothing, especially dark clothing: worn, shabby. [from 17th c.]
examples: He wore a black jacket, rusty and amorphous.

entries.meaning: Affected with the fungal plant disease called rust.

description: Ellipsis of rusty one more often used for this, or from the general epithet rusty given to various particular firearm names—earlier both was applied in Cockney rhyming slang for other machines, including swords in their day, but the present coinage has not more than a loose connection to this and is from the preference for used or antique firearms due to their being easier or cheaper to obtain.

entries.meaning: (MLE, slang) A gun or in particular an old or worn one.

description: Variant form of resty; compare also reasty.

adjectives.description: rusty (comparative more rusty, superlative most rusty)
